Award.AwardTitle: PHoTOnICs: PHysics with Tablets Outside and Inside Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of the PHoTOnICs project, led by researchers at the University of California, Davis, is two-fold: First, the researchers will design technology-based learning activities that seize on emerging digital devices as resources for extending best practices in physics instruction. Second, they will conduct research into the nature of student learning and collaborative interaction supported by those curricular designs and technologies, particularly tablet and mobile PCs of the kind that are quickly becoming widespread on college campuses and in many K-12 school settings. The research will take place in an introductory series of college physics courses at UC Davis and in the West Sacramento Early College Prep Charter School, a diverse, urban school that has a focus on bridging formal and informal learning experiences by utilizing mobile technology. As part of this project, the investigators will develop assessments of student learning of specific physics content as well as their developing reasoning and problem solving abilities in physics.

The project will capitalize on digital technologies and their prominence in many students' informal activity by integrating them into designs for learning activities in formal science education settings. Mobile devices offer distinctive potential for bridging informal and formal learning environments because of their ready portability across settings and their utility in supporting a broad range of activities. A central focus of the proposed project will be to develop and study the use of technology in education by supporting student collaboration both inside and outside the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project focused on designing and studying a set of novel technology applications for college and high school physics classrooms. Over the last 15 years, computer-based simulations have emerged as a powerful resource for enabling science students to visualize complex phenomena, model dynamic processes, and investigate relationships between elements of physical systems. The advent of mobile computing devices with networking capabilities, touchscreen interfaces and built-in sensors has occasioned new opportunities for extending the benefits of simulations into new settings and instructional configurations. Our project has focused on leveraging these capabilities to support interactive and collaborative learning activities. We have created and studied several tablet and web-based tools and scenarios to support collaborative learning about physics in high school and university classrooms.  Each of the PHoTOnICs designs aims to present learners with simulation elements on their own devices they must coordinate with those on the screens of other students in their small group to explore physical phenomena represented by relationships among those elements.

Primary outcomes of this project include two collaborative simulations for introductory physics classrooms. One application, called “Making Waves”, provides a platform for participants to collectively construct a traveling wave simulation. A primary goal of this tool is to help students make sense of the relationship between the sinusoidal oscillations, in time, of each point along a wave, and the sinusoidal oscillation across the entire collection of points, in space. In sequences of tasks of building waves with different wavelengths and direction of travel, students investigate the relations between the motions and phases of individual oscillators, the relative motions of neighboring oscillators, and the collective wave motion. Another application, called “E-Fields”, allows for collaborative visualization of charged particle interactions.  Students can add particles, change their charge and strength and activate visualizations for field lines, field vectors, force vectors, and equipotential surfaces.  Students can also use tools to draw estimated vectors and drop test charges.  As students make changes, the views of other students in a group are updated in near real-time providing opportunities for collaborative discussion and learning. The “Making Waves” and “E-Fields” apps are available to teachers and their students on a UC Davis-hosted public website, and can be readily accessed and run in an internet browser on tablets, smartphones and personal computers.

Both the "Making Waves" and "E-Fields" applications were designed on the premise that learners’ understanding of individual-to-collective relationships in physics, such as that between electric charges and fields, or between oscillators and waves leverage a congruence between the interactional space of the small group and the conceptual space of physics, could be supported through collaborative simulations and learning activities where those relationships corresponded with peer interactions and individual contributions to group tasks. Over the course of the four-year project, several high school and university physics instructors in schools in Northern California used these tools and activities with their classes. While they did so, members of the research team observed and recorded the ways students used the technology and the kinds of reasoning and problem-solving conversations they participated in with their peers. Through these investigations, we have found that the individual displays to which each student had access supported reasoning about representations of these physical systems and created a shared context in which students had both a common problem-solving goal and a shared set of tools with which to solve it. Moreover, distributing control over elements of the simulation across multiple students’ devices promoted a positive interdependence of student contributions, requiring the group to coordinate their interactions to successfully complete the shared tasks.

A final project outcome involves the significant research mentorship, training, and professional development opportunities it provided for a number of UC Davis students and physics educators who participated in the project. Two graduate students served as members of the research team over the course of the project, including one PhD student who completed dissertation research directly related to project activities and data. Three high school teachers and several university physics instructors in the region implemented project technology and activities with hundreds of their students over the lifetime of the grant. And more than one hundred other middle and high school mathematics teachers and teaching credential candidates had opportunities to work with and learn from the tools and materials developed throughout the project in the context of professional development workshops and teacher education courses.
